title: typographic holiday gift?
content:
i am trying to find something typographic (other than a CD of typefaces) that i can buy/steal/make/acquire for my graphic designer girlfriend for the holidays this year - any ideas? i have already been through the Veer catalog, as well as some of the foundries, and a T-shirt is not really what i am looking for. something unique, beautiful, and made of or insipred by typography. It does not neccesarily need to be super cheap - id like to get her something nice. jewlery? handmade typographic clock? i am at a loss here.

any thoughts?
author: shecky

comments.content: How do you feel about giving books? How does she feel about receiving books?

_As seen on [Typographica](http://web.archive.org/web/20131019033508/http:/typographi.com/001037.php)_:

[ViaLetter](http://web.archive.org/web/20131019033508/http:/www.vialetter.com/)

You could buy her name. Or a cute message like your intials plus her initials (AB+CD).

Also: [http://typographi.com/001040.php](http://web.archive.org/web/20131019033508/http:/typographi.com/001040.php "http://typographi.com/001040.php")

If she has any sense she will probably love the Kern Zipper Hoodie.

Ooo... also seen recently at [BoingBoing](http://web.archive.org/web/20131019033508/http:/www.boingboing.net/2005/11/26/giant_freestanding_l.html):

[SET26 (Giant letter bookshelves/cabinets)](http://web.archive.org/web/20131019033508/http:/www.set26.ch/) (though that site is in German and I'm not sure if they're actually for sale in the US).

I would move ahead with the "typographic clock". Find out her top 12 faces, and assign one to each hour (ransom note style). Or make all the digits in the same one. Or no digits at all -- assign letters and reinvent her concept of time. I'm sure she'll be into meeting you for a date at L:RC o'clock. Plus, making it yourself beats anything you'll find for sale at veer (sorry veer).

The best typographic gift I recieved was the "CTS Photo display catalog" (a phone book sized type specimen collection). Not the most obscure collection, but for graphic designers, seeing a face in print helps with type choice far better than screen previews. Plus, there's a perverse collection of swashes and unseemly ligatures.
Doesn't Veer, FontShop or MyFonts have gift certificates?

Pentagram has a typographic calendar that is pretty swell. Here's a link to a description, and a link on the page to order as well.

[http://www.moleskinerie.com/2005/11/pentagram\_2006\_.html](http://web.archive.org/web/20131019033508/http:/www.moleskinerie.com/2005/11/pentagram_2006_.html "http://www.moleskinerie.com/2005/11/pentagram\_2006\_.html")

If she is interested in historical modernism you could consider the [Stendig Calender](http://web.archive.org/web/20131019033508/http:/www.unicahome.com/catalog/item.asp?id=4335), I loved having mine. (Funny: They photoshopped the new year into the image. ewww)
Or [this calendar](http://web.archive.org/web/20131019033508/http:/www.unicahome.com/catalog/item.asp?id=7037) if she enjoys routinely flipping pages every day. Never have to buy a new one, I guess.
... and I second Tiffany's "ewww"

eBay, under **Business and Industrial \> Printing and Graphic Arts \> Graphic Arts Essentials** has LOTS of letterpress cuts and woodtype up for auction at ANY given time. There's something charming and captivating about these "artifacts," and they can make quite attractive decor as well. Of course, going the auction route is always hit or miss -- someone else may REALLY want that item that has caught your fancy but, as often as not, some real gems gets overlooked and can be had at a VERY reasonable price.

I once gave the typographic quartett as a gift to somebody, and she loved it.

your friend needs to be quite a geek though ;-)

The whole Storm Type collection, for example, catalog, poster and all.

Nothin' says lovin' like about 1,000 Euro's worth of some of the best typefaces on the planet. Hell, you can even have the CD autographed by Frantisek Storm himself.

Stop trying to be unique and different. Just be predictable and extremely generous. ;-)

I think any graphic designer would definitely love the entire [_Great Ideas_](http://web.archive.org/web/20131019033508/http:/www.penguin.co.uk/static/cs/uk/0/articles/greatideas/) set from Penguin. Loverly typographic covers adorn some inspiring—if not downright revolutionary—texts from smarty-pants know-it-alls like Nietzsche, Woolf, Freud, Orwell, Marx and others.

Michel de Montaign's essay _On Friendship_ is so moving I almost cried... in a laundromat. IN A LAUNDROMAT.

You, my friend, will be a romantic hero when this gift is opened, and I want royalties on all the love you get.

If you got the bucks or win the lottery you can get her one of [Eric Gill's](http://web.archive.org/web/20131019033508/http:/www.ericgill.com/index.php) praised [**engraved illustrations**](http://web.archive.org/web/20131019033508/http:/www.ericgill.com/view_art.php?art_id=1086&min=0&max=10000000&portrait=&original=&sub=&sort_by=&sold=) with type, printed from the original blocks!

_His prints first appeared invariably in tiny editions or as illustrations in limited edition books, such as those he illustrated for the Golden Cockerel Press. We are fortunate that in 1929 his friend and publisher, Douglas Cleverdon, produced a book of his prints, all printed from the original blocks. This was followed 5 years later by a second similar book, this time published by Faber._

And they already framed!

I guess I would have trouble owning anything Eric Gill touched.
